The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

MONDAY, MARCH 6, 1905.

div.head: THE STRUGGLE FOR MUKDEN
div.p: Great battle, whioh has been raging for the last few days, is going in favor of the Japanese, and a Reuter's telegram, despatched from Niu yesteroday, declares that the i are burning the station and stores at Mukden preparatory to retreating. Mukden falls into the hands of the Japanese, it will be the crowning defeat of thirteen months of un- broken disaster, and Will render the task of suing for terms of one of a nondurable humiliation. A single transitory gleam of victory on the Russianeagles would restore the national self- respect. In well-informed circles in Paris, it is believed that any suooess, however inde- cisive, on the part of Kuropatkin would pave the way to peace. However, the latest news from the front seems to show that such a con- summation is a long way off. The oonfused re- port reach us indicate that anotber Russian defeat is in progress, and that the Russian flank is in serious danger of being turned, if, indeed, that hasnot already taken place. There is nothing which indicates that the Russians have reversed, or are likely to reverse, their proved inferiority in the field. They lost heavi- ly in the murderous battles of September and October last and we have no reneon to sup- pose that thereinforcements which have reach- ed them are better in quality than tbe men whose place they supply. Indeed, the Russian Army, numbers apart is a less formidable fighting machine than when Kuropatkin first took the field. The lamentable dissensions which followed the last battle make it diffi- cult to believe that the generalissimo still retains the unbroken confidence of his men. A discouraged army is an army already poten- tially defeated, and the continuous reverses which tbe Russians have sustained, empha- sized as they are in this latest conflict inevitably tend to weaken them in this, per- ps the final struggle.

div.head: Condition of Russia
Elective Assembly Summonded
div.p: St. Petersburg, March 4.

The Tsar has addressed a rescript to the Minister of the Interior in which he says that it is his resolve to convene the most worthy men in the Empire, elected by the people, to participate in the legislation of the country, though at the same time it is necessary to preserve absolutely the immutability of the fundamental laws of the empire (Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, March 4.

Aftre yesterday Morning's Manifesto the russian public was estonished by the publication yesterday evening of the rescript intimating the Tsar's intention to summon in some form an elective assembly to participate in the legislation of the country. The newspapers express great satisfaction but the public, generally, hesitates, awaiting developments (R.)
Warsaw, March 4.
The strike of the gasworkers here has ended. (Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, March 4.
The newspapers have welcomed the Tsar's Rescript. (Havas.)
St. Perersburg March 5.
The Strikes have increased here. 51000 strikers are now out. Yesterday passed quietly.
Reuter.

div.head: The Charcot Expedition
Safe Return to Port Madrin
div.p: Buenos Ayres, March 5.
The Charcot expedition has returned Safely to Port Madrin. (Havas)

div.head: Mr. Roosevelt
New Presidential Term
div.p: Mr. Roosevelt has formally inaugrated the new presidential term at the Capitol with the usual ceremonial. (Reuter.)

div.head: LFirst Lord of the Admiralty
Earl Cawdor Appointed
div.p: London, March 5.
Earl Cawdor has been appointed first Lord of the Admiralty. (Reuter.)

div.head: TREMENDOUS BATTLE
MUKDEN IN DANGER
RUSSIANS PREPARING TO RETREAT.
Signal Victory of Japs.
div.p: Tokio, March 1

Many of the Russian positions ares so strongly fortified- that siege methods.are necessary capturing them. . The Russians on the right bank of the Hunho have delivered heavy counter attacks, which, however, have Been repulsed. Oku has occupied the important posit Chang-Tan. (Reuter.)
London. March 4

Renter's correspondent with Oku cables that the last day's casualties as regards the Japanese amounted to 2,000, the Russians being greater. The bombardment continues along the railway in a heavy snowstorm. (Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, March 4

General Kuropatkin reports tie loss of part of the Gaotuling defences on the 3rd inst. The attack continued all yesterday. The fighting on the left flank was generally of a most severe and desperate character. The Japanese attacks were again repulsed. In some places the enemy made ramparts with their own dead. Over 20. Japanese battalions were yesterday repuised at Kandolisan terrible losses. (Reuter.)
Tokio, March 4
Oku has captured nine miles of positions the Russian right. The fighting continues fiercely to-day along the entire front. The Japanese are »U gaining. . (Reuter.)
London, March 4
A despatch from Vladivostok states that 2,000 Japanese have landed at Shengudshin to the north of Korea. (Reuter.)
Tokio, March 4.
A general action is doubtful, Nevertheless there has been an important battle at Chi- piughai, where the Russians, after their defeat fell back on Tscheugchekban. (Havas.)
Murkden, March 5.
The Japanese advanced posts extend parallel with the railway to within 9 miles of the town but the movements of their troops are being continually paralysed.
General Kuropatkiu is taking the offensive in the centre. (Havas).
London, March 5.

Reuter's correspondent with Kuroki reports that on the 4tg inst. the Japanese gained a signal victory beyond the Hun-Ho. They defeated two divisions of the 16th Corps, recently arrived from Europe, with great slaughter, and captured huge quantities ammunition.

The same correspondent reports that on the 4th inst. the Japanese were tremendouslu bombarding the strongholds on the Russian left with heavy siege guns. It seems impossible that the strongholds .will long withstand projectiles of such a weight. (Reuter)
Niu-Chwano, March 5.
The latest reports show that the Russians are burning the station and stores at Mukden preparatory to retreating. (Reuter)
Tokio, March 5.

Oyama continues to make great drives round both flanks of the Russians. His front now forms a huge bow with a base on the Sha-Ho. The right arm reaches a point east of Fushu and the left arm extends to a point west of Mukden. Marshal Oyama is steadily tightening the great cordon round Kuropatkid, who is striving desperately to check these advances and is contesting the flank encroachments by hammering the Japanese centre. (Renter.)
Mukden, March 5.
A tremendous battle is raging round the town positions., The Japanese ten times charged Kaudolisan but were repulsed. The . Russians also repulsed 13 charges against ' Kaotuling Pass. (Reuter.

div.head: BAKU IN STATE OF SIEGE.
div.p: -St. Petersburg, March 4.
A state of siege has been proclaimed in the Province of Baku. (Reuter.)

The Ministry has resigned. The Chamber of Deputies has adjourned. (Havas.)

The Cabinet has resigned, following the resignation of the Premier on the ground of ill-health. (Reuter.)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Mahmal left Mecca on Saturday for Jeddah.
The Plague.—During last week only one case of plague was reported in Egypt, and at Suez.
Shrove Tuesday.—The preparations for the battle of confetti at Ghezireh Palace to-morrow are almost completed, and a fine spectacle is promised.
New Assize Court.—This morning the new Assize Court at Cairo was inaugurated in the presence ofMinisters of Justice and the Interior. The Court sat in the Native Appeal Court.
The Cairo Omnibus Company, has, it is said been authorised by the Ministry of Public Works to use motor buses between Masri- Kadima and Foum el Khalig and thence to Said Zenab.
Mr. Scott-Leslie,the Society entertainer, is giving a recital at Mouferrato's Hall on Saturday next, assisted by' Mr. David W, Norton, pianist, and several well-known local amateurs.
The Hired Transport “Dilwara” left Alex- andria on Saturday afternoon having on board N0. 5 Ca, Royal Malta Artillery; for Malta, and the 56th Battery, Royal Field Artillery, for Southampton.

Sailors and Soldiers’ Institute. — Rev. Wm. Bramley-Moore, M.A of London, will give a lecture, illustrated by diagrams, on the Tabernacle of Moses, this evening at 8 o'clock, at the Sailors and Soldiers' Institute, Alex- audria.

Novelli at Alexandria. — Owing to the grounding of the Florio-Rubattino S.S. “Cairo," the debut of Sig. Novell's company at the Zizinia Theatre has been postponed, the stage properties and costumes being on board the vessel.

Bovine Typhus.—32 deaths from bovine typhus were reported throughout Egypt last week. During the corresponding week last year 3,947 deaths occurred. The number of deaths registered since the beginning of the epidemic amounts to 146,873.

Suez Canal.—20 vessels passed through the Canal on the 2und inst., 7 of which were British, 1 Norwegian, 1 Austrian, 9 German, 1 French, 1 Danish. The day's receipts were its. 511,874.36, making the total for 1st and 2nd inst., Irs. 871,620.39.

Cairo Blooms.—Amateur rose growers may be interested to hear that a gentleman, not unconnected with finance, has just succeed- ed in carrying two boxes of cut blooms from Cairo to London, and keeping them alive for six days alter their arrival.

The Jesuits’ College. —The Lent lectures at the Jesuits College at Alexandria will be held in the college chapel every Saturday at 6.30 p.m., commencing on tins 11th inst. Father Louis Perroy, S.J., will be the lecturer. The ladies’ retreat will take place on Satur- day, 3rd April, and Friday, 7th April.

Alhambra Theatre.—The performances of the “Chat Noir" company on Saturday and yesterday were a groat success. The last per- formance will be given to-morrow, when there will also be a matinee performance at reduced prices. The fancy-dress ball to-morrow night, on the occasion of Shrove Tuesday, promises b to be a great success. Prizes will be given for the best costumes.

A Wolf in Town.—A wolf which had pro- bably made its way into the town from the dessert, attacked a man on Friday in a street near the Custom House and terribly mauled him. Four men and a boy, who came to the man’s rescue, were also bitten by the animal, which was found to be suffering from hydrophobia. It was captured by the police and shot, while its unfortunate victims were removed to hospital and subsequently sent to the Pasteur insti- tute, Cairo.

Anolo-American Co.—The splendid steamer 8t of the Anglo-American Nile Navigation Com- pany, the "Mayflower," which left Cairo on Friday, will take a number, of Mr. Clark’s tourists oh board at Luxor. The steamer has the usual Urge complement of passengers on » board and, on taking in the extra passengers on at Luxor, will not have a berth vacant. This season has been a record one for the Anglo- American Line, both as regards its tourist traffic and its hotel, for the Savoy at Assouan is doing wonderfully well.

div.head: DAIRA SANIEH COMPANY.
SIR W. WILLCQCKS’ RESIGNATION.
div.p: We are in a position to state that it is highly probable Sir Wm. Willcocks will resign his post of managing director of the Daira. Sa- nieh Company on the 15th inst., and will be replaced by Harari Pasha.

div.head: THE BRITISH GARRIS0N.
ORDER BY DUKE OF CONNAUGHT
div.p: The following order was issued by H.R.H. the Inspector General of the Forces on his departure from Egypt:—

"H.R.H. the Inspector General of the Forces was much pleased with what he saw of the Garrisons of Khartoum, Cairo, and Alexandria, during his recent inspections, and congratulates the General Officer Commanding in Egypt on the state of his Command.”

div.head: INTERESTING FIND AT SAKKARAH.
div.p: A most interesting find is reported from Sakkarah. Some of the natives digging Sebbak unearthed a granite statue, bearing a royal cartouche, seated on a throne or cart from which the wheels had been lost, while before him stood two lions in bronze with golden eyes, held by leashes or reins.
The Government watchmen soon found out about this important discovery and seized the piece for the Cairo Museum.
More alert than ever, they now watched carefully and were rewarded by seeing a bronze stela come to light.
We hope soon to see these treasures exposed to view, before the season closes.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive has despatched to the Gover- nor of Alexandria the brevets and insignia of the ranks and decorations which his Highness recently bestowed on the Councillors of the Alexandria Municipality and other local nota- bles.

His Highness received John Bey Haicalis in private audience at Abdeen Palace this morning, in order to receive the thanks of the Bey for the touching proofs of sympathy which his Highness had manifested on the recent death of his father, Dr. Haicalis Pasha, the founder and editor of the ‘Phare d’Alexandrie.”
His Highness presided at a Council of Min- isters, held at Abdeen Palace, this morning.
. This evening his Highness will give a ban- quet in honor of Major-General Slade, C.B.

div.head: FIERCE SANDSTORM.
( From our Correspondent. )
div.p: - Port Said, Sunday.

The train which left Cairo last night at 6.15 and should have arrived here at 11 p.m., did not arrive until a quarter to six this morning. The delay was due to the strong wind and heavy sandstorm which was sweeping across the line. The train was detained at Ismailia for four hours as it was thought dangerous for it to continue in face of such a storm. Much delay is also anticipated again this evening, as although the storm abated daring the day, it is raging now with renewed force.

div.head: Abbas Helmy Theatre
div.p: Giordano’s opera Fedora was given on Satur- day night with Signa. Bassich in the title role. The part on the whole suits her, and she was much applauded all through the evening. The performance was also a success for the two tenors, Signori Pagani and Montanari.

The performance of Traviata last night was • good. Signor Tomisani scored a brilliant success n the role of Alfredo. He sang the sweet romance of the 3rd act with wonderful delicacy of tone. Signa. Tadolini was a good Violetta. Sig. Montanari again distinguished himself.
This evening Rigoletto will be given for the benefit of the tenor Sig. Tomisani, and we aope to see a bumper house.

div.head: . GROUNDING OF S S. “CAIRO.”
RUBATTINO STEAMER IN DANGEROUS POSITION.
RESCUE OF PASSENGERS
div.p: The Florio-Rubattino Company'jS. 8. “Cairo," which was due at Alexandria from Italy at 8 am. yesterday, was not signalled until 7.80 p.m. yesterday. At 8.10^p.m; the vessel entered the Boghaz Pass steaming quite slowly. Daring her passage through the pass she twice stopped her machines and when she arrived near the red lighthouse, she again, stopped. At length she made a sadden tarn and appeared to be trying to go back to sea through the Boghaz. For some minutes she steamed in this direction, and then stopped short suddenly at 9.10 p.m., having run on a bank or a rook. Her right side is under water, her bow facing N. W. The point where she has struck, is known as the Agame shoal.

When the steamer struck,the first officer went pff in a small boat and informed the port authorities of the disaster. No tug was able to get near the vessel’ during the night owing to the high sea running, and the passen- gers and crew were only taken off this morning at 7.15. Some of the passengers were up to the ire breast in water when taken off, as the waves on beat against the vessel with terrific force, rolling her terribly, and it is considered extraordinary that no lives were lost. The mails and cargo have not yet been recovered, and nothing can be done until the weather gets better. If the sea continues high nothing will be saved.

The “Cairo” had encountered very bad weather since leaving Messina. Captain De Marchi states that he came to the pass ex- pecting to find a pilot, but after looking about for one in vain, he was trying to get to sea again, when the vessel struck.
An enquiry has been opened at the Italian Consulate.
The great Italian actor Novelli was on board, and he and his company have lost all their baggage.
There were about 100 passengers on board.

The following is an eye-witness’s account — I happened be at Mex last night, and between 8.30 and 9 o’clock I saw a steamer’s lights in a very unusual position close to the coast. Soon after the vessel fired off several rockets, and continued to do so until past midnight. At 10.30 o’clock I noticed the lights of the Port tug going out to the wreck, but apparently she could not get very close. A heavy sea was running and the steamer rolled heavily. From the portion of the fights one could see that there was a heavy list, which apparently got worse and worse. At about 11.30 I thought that all was over, for she rolled right over and the fights disappeared. But she righted herself later and the lights again came into view. At about 5.30 a.m. the position of the boat was clearly discernible. Four tugs were around her, taking off passen- gers, and at 7 a.m. the togs left the wreck, which seemed to be sinking - fast by the stern, and steamed towards the harbour. The wreck is half-way between Mex and Dekheleh and the steamer to all appearances was a mile out, of her ‘course when she struck.

div.head: Raising of S.S. “Congal”
(From our Correspondent.)
div.p: Port Said, Sunday.

The owners of the salvage steamer "Hermes,” which arrived from Constantinople the other day have sent in the estimate Ot the cost of were ing the Norwegian steamer "Congal,” but the amount is not known. If the estimate is ac cepted operations will be started immediately. The method employed will be that of inflated rubber bags’. The engine-room end cabins are to be filled and a large number of these bags are to be attached to the sides of the vessel below waterline and inflated with air.

div.head: CAIRO SOLDIERS' CLUB.
div.p: A most successful smoking concert was given in the above club last Friday evening, a large amount of talent being discovered amongst the new members, while that of the older members was as enjoyable as ever. Among the new members, the songs given by Sergt. Malyon, R.A.M.C.,Corpl.Royle, M.M.P., and Sapper Newton, R.E,, were extremely well rendered, While that of Mr. George Holmes, amongst the older members of the club, was given in his usual delightful manner.

During the interval, the prizes tor the bil- liard handicaps were presented by Major- General Slade, C.B, who gave to each recipient a few well-chosen words of praise and encourage- ment. In acknowledging a vote of thanks proposed by Capt. Bayley), the General spoke a very feeling manner, referring to his early departure from the command and from the Service, in which he had spent forty-four years. He advised the men not to leave the Service, but to persevere and go on in a straight line doing their duty, which he assured them would bring a prosperous and happy time.

The General’s remarks were receiverd with hearty and prolonged cheering, the whole of the audience rising spontaneously and singing “For he's a jolly good fellow," the cheering being continued as the General took his departure.
All ranks feel the less of General Slade, who at all times has taken a keen interest, not only in the Soldiers' Club, but in they of every one under his command.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: 2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN.
THE SIRDAR’S VISIT.
(From Our Correspondent).
div.p: Suakin, February 24.
The weather here during the past few months has been very odd, but there has been no rain worth mentioning.

Great preparations are being made here for the reception of H. E. the Sirdar and Governor- General of the Sudan, Sir R. Wingate Pasha, who is expected here about the first week in March. Several Government buildings will be decorated for the occasion and triumphal arches are being erected at several places through which his Excellency will pass in making his entry into Suakin. Inspector Bailey, Suakin Railways, has been entrusted with the erection of a new railway platform 150 feet long opposite the Shata Gate, where his Excellency will alight from the train and then ride to Government House.

The Sirdar will come overland vii Athara to Railheed and from Railhead by special train to Suakin, so that his Excellency will be enabled to inspect the new line. The Suakin Cosmopolitan Orchestra are preparing a special entertainment to be given during the Sirdar’s short stay here, and it is hoped his Excellency will honor this entertainment with his presence. It is feared that Sir Rudolph von Slatin Pasha, Ins- pector-General of the Sudan, will not be able to accompany the Sirdar to Suakin, as he has only just toft Khartoum for Kordo- fan on a very important mission.

Mr. George Urquhart, bridge contractor, Suakin-Atbara Railways, has just completed, the erection of the first bridge of 105' span at Nambok station. The 2nd, 3rd and 4th bridges to be erected at Sallom station are also well advanced. These bridges are also of 105' span each.

El Minim Macauley Bey, R.E., Director, Sudan Rail ways, went by special train on the 20th inst. as far as Railhead, which is now by Komobsana, and made a general inspection of all the stations and work on the lines. He re- turned to Snakin on the 23rd inst.

The Khedivial mail steamer “Gharbieh” arrived here from Suez on the 23rd inst. and landed Mr. Guido Corbetta, the contractor of the National Bank of Egypt and the Quaran- tine Camp, at Suakin. He has come in connec- tion with some important contracts for Suakin Barghoot Port. Several workmen also arrived by the "Gharbieh” for the Suakin-Atbara Railways.

The Khedivial mail steamer “Mahallah” arrived from Suez on the 11th inst, having on board Miralai Howard Bey, Moudir of Suakin, also Messrs. Pearlman and Howe, both of them formerly in the employ of the Behera Land Company. Mr. Pearlman has been appointed Assistant District Traffic Manager, and Mr. owe Inspector of Bridge work, Suakin- Atbara Railways. Mr. Howe is well known at Sidi-Gaber, Alexandria.

Captain Brooke-Smith, of the Sudan Govern- ent steamer ‘ Mukhbir,” has been transferred to the Sudan Government steamer “Tyra,” to to alter the pearl fishing around Suakin. The "Tyra” left Suakin on the 13th inst. for the purpose of supervising the pearl fisheries and returned here on the 18th inst.

Those unlucky condensers again ! Mr. May- lor, the erecting engineer of the Suakin Rail- way condensers, has been in hospital with blood poisoning, but is now completely cured, and hopes to have the condenser ready for trial in a week or so. The old condensers, which were saved from the wreck of the S.S. "Afghan- istan,” have now been taken over by the Suakin Railway from the insurance agents, and are being thoroughly overhauled. They will be erected either here or at Sheikh Bar ghoot, but most probably at Suakin, as a second condenser here is necessary to provide against an accident, or the need of repairs to the one already erected.

The Suakin International Club have remov- 1 to another building, formerly occupied by the branch of the National Bank of Egypt The honorary president is Mr. G. C. Kerr, Deputy Inspector, Suakin Moudirieh, and its members now number over 30. The new club contains a large billiard-room, reading-room, concert-hall with piano, etc., a splendid bar, gymnasium etc.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: We regret to announce the death of Mr. Clinton Baker, who died at Cure on Saturday diphtheria. The funeral took place yesterday. Mr. Baker was a member, of the\ English Bar and only recently came to Egypt an arrangement with the Sudan Govern- ment in order to practice at Khartoum. He, however, returned to Cairo, as the climate in Sudan did not agree with him.

We regret to learn of the death, which took place at Alexandria yesterday, of M. Nicholas Zananiri, of the well-known and respected Za- naniri family. The funeral will take place this afternoon at 4 o'clock, from deceased’s house in Cairo station street.

The following passengers, left Shellal on Sunday by. the P.S. "Prince Abbas” :—Misses M. and J. Bridges, Miss J. B. Ward, Mr. Mr. R.. Prance, Wm. Hicks, Mr. and Mrs. W. T. Horses nominated under the old conditions will be considered as left in under the altered conditions of the race if not withdrawn by the 1st April 1905. Unless 20 horses are left in or entered the race will not he considered to have filled.
The other conditions remain the same.
A. S. Prsotoh,

Football

Owing to a football match having been arranged between a team of the P. & 0. Com- pany's S. S. “Vectis” and that of Alexandria, the far holes of the golf course will not he available for play to-morrow afternoon.
A Rugby football match has been arranged to be played on the polo ground of the A.S.C. on Saturday afternoon, 11th inst., from 8 to 4 p.m.
HELOUAN 8PORTING CLUB.

At a committee meeting of the H. 8. C. held on Friday it was decided to postpone the Helouan Spring Skye Meeting to Friday, 17th inst. Consequently the entries are open until Saturday, 11th March, for all races except for the "Ladies’ Bracelet,” which race is already closed. •

div.head: THE DAIRA SANIEH COMPANY LIMITED. ‘
notice to shareholders.
div.p: In accordance with the terms of the Additional Article Of the 4 th Julie 1904 to the Agreement 18th November 1905, enter entered into between the Comptrollers of the Daira Sanieh, acting under the authority of their respective Governements, and the Daira Sanieh Company Limited, the Directors how propose to constitute a Company under Egyptian Law which is to take over the assets and liabilities of this Company. A draft Agreement for this purpose will be submitted for consideration at the Extraordinary General Meeting of the Shareholders to be held on the 27th inst.
On same day, separate meetings of the holders of Ordinary and of Deferred Shares will be held in accordance with Article 25 of the Articles of Association. • S. De Bilinskii,
Secretary.
Sharia Kasr-el-Nil,
Cairo, 4th March 1905.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the Daira Sanieh Company, Limited, will be held at the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo, on Monday the 27th day of March 1905 at 8 o’clock in the afternoon for the purpose of considering and, if thought fit, passing the subjoined Extraordinary Resolution. RESOLUTION.

That the Board be authorised to enter into an Agreement with a Company about to be formed under Egyptian Law with the title of "La Société Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh” or some similar title, or with a Trustee for such Company, in the ’ terms of a draft which will^ be submitted to the Meeting, subject to such modifications as the Board may think fit, for the sale to such company of the whole of the undertaking, business and assets * of the Company, subject to its liabilities, and. that this Meeting hereby sanctions the scheme of distribution of the proceeds of sale therein provided for.
Dated this fourth day of March 1905.
By Order of the Board.
S. DE Bilinski,
Secretary.
Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo.

A draft of the Agreement can be seen in Cairo at the Offices of tho Company, Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, and at the Offices of Maitre Carton de Wia'rt, Legal Adviser to the Com pany, at nny time during business hours during the ten days immediately preceding the Meeting, and in London ‘ at the Offices of Messrs. Norton, Rose, Norton, Faruh & Co., the Solicitors for tho Company, 57$ Old Broad Street, E.C., at any time during busiuess hours during the fifteen days immediately preceding tho Meeting. Shareholders holding Share Warrants to Bearer, who wish to attend the above Meeting, must first deposit their Bearer Warrants, together with a statement of their names and addresses, either with the National Bank of Egypt, in Cairo or Alexandria, two clear days before the date of the Meeting (viz., not later than 24th March), or with the National Bank of Egypt in London, 4 and 5, King William Street; E-C ten clear days before the date of the Meeting (viz., not later than 15th March), the Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the Meeting shall have been held. Depositor will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange for the Share Warrants deposited, and a ticket of admission (which must be produced by the holder attending the Meeting) and Forms of Proxy,

If the Depositor does not intend personally to attend the meeting, a proxy in favor of the person producing the Certificate must be lodged .with, the National Bank of Egypt in Cairo or Alexandria not loss than forty-eight hours before the Meeting.

NOTICE .IS HEREBY GIVEN that a meeting of the Ordinary Shareholders of the Daira Sanieh. Company Limited will be held .at the National Bank of Egy'pt in Cairo on Monday the 17th day of March 1905, at 8.30 o’clock in the afternoon or so soon thereafter as the Extraordinary General Meeting convened for 3 o’clock may have terminated, for the purpose of considering and, if drought fit, passing the subjoined Extraordinary Resolution. That the Board be authorised to enter into an Agreement with, a Company about to be formed under Egyptian Law with the title of “La Société Egyotienne de la Daira Sanieh” or some similar title, or with a Trustee for such Company, in the terms of the draft which will be submitted to to the Meeting, subject to such modifications as the Board may think fit, for the sale to such Company of whole of the undertaking, business and assets of the Com- pany to its liabilities, and that this Meeting hereby sanction the Scheme of distribution of the proceeds of gala therein provided for; add any modification affecting or any abrogation of the right and privileges of the holders of the Ordinary Shares under such scheme of distribution.
Dated this fourth day of March 1905.
By order of the Board,
S. DE Bilinski,
Secretary
Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo.

A draft, of the Agreement can be seen in Cairo at the offices of the Company, Sharia Kasr el-Nil and at the offices of Maitre Carton de Wiarrt, Legal Adviser to the Company, at any time during| business hours during the ten days immediately preceding the Meeting, and in London at the offices of Messrs, Norton, Rose, Norton, Farish & Co., the Solicitors for the Company , 57 ½, Old Broad Street, E.C., at any time during business hours during the fifteen days immediately preceding the Meeting.
Rose, Norton, Farish & Co., the Solicitors for the Company , 57 ½, Old Broad Street, E.C., at any time during business hours during the fifteen days immediately preceding the Meeting.

Ordinary Shareholders holding Share War­rants to Bearer, who wish to attend the above Meeting must first deposit their Bearer Warrants, together with a statement of their names and addresses, either with the National Bank of Egypt, in Cairo or Alexandria, two clear days before the date of the. Meeting (viz., not later than 24th March), or with the Na­tional Bank of Egypt, in London, 4 and 6, King William Street, E. C., ten clear days before the date of the Meeting (via, not later than 15th March), the Share Warrants remain­ing so deposited until after the Meeting shall have been held.

Each Depositor will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange lot the Share Warrants deposited, and a ticket of admission (which must be produced by the holder attending the Meeting) and Forms of Proxy.

It the Depositor does not intend personally to attend the Meeting, a Proxy in favor of the person producing the Certificate must be lodged with the National Bank of Egypt in Cairo or Alexandria not less than forty-eight hours before the Meeting.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that a Meeting of the Deferred Shareholders of the Daira Sanieh Company Limited will be held at the National Bank of Egypt in Cairo on Monday the 27th March 1906, at 4 o'clock in the afternoon or. so soon thereafter as the Meeting of Ordinary shareholders convened for 8.30 o'clock may have terminated, for the, purpose of considering and, if- thought fit, passing the subjoined Extraordinary Resolu­tion.
RESOLUTION.

That the Board be authorised to enter into en Agreement with a Company about to be formed under Egyptian Law with tihe title of ■)La Société Egyptienne de la Daria Sanieh” or some similar title, or with a Trustee for such Company, in the terms of the draft which will be submitted to the Meeting, subject to such modifications as the Board may think fit, for the sale to such Company of the' whole of the undertaking, business and assets of' the Company, subject to its liabilities, and that this Meeting hereby sanctions toe scheme of distribution of the proceeds of sale therein provided for and any modification affecting or any abrogation of the rights and privileged of the holders of the Deferred shares under such scheme of distribution.

By order of the Board
S. de Bn.inski,

div.head: BOURSE KHEDIVIALE
div.p: Remarwues sur le marché du disponsible et des contrats
Samedi, le 4 mars 1905.

Disponsible-; La demande pir le disponuble a été bonne et elle a surtout porté sur les cotons supérieurs et les qualites basses de 5 à 7 talaries. Quant `a la cote, par suite de la situation des contrats, elle se présente avec une baisse de 1/8 de talari comme réaumee de la semaine.
Franco-Station. –– On n'ya fait rien.

Contrats. - Nonvelle récolte. Le marché a été suffisamment actif et les cours en resteant relativement soutenus. La spéculation s'y porte de pls en plus sur l'annonce que les semailles sont en retard et que l"Angleterre a fair quel ques achats assez importants sur novembre.

Récolte actuelle. –– Elle a été plutôt calme et finit en recul sur la semaine dernière; mais au fond, le ton est toujours bon et on compte beaucoup sur le décon vert de mars et de mai. Pour le moment, il y a rapprochement entre ces deux mois.
Dans la matinée:prix plus haut pour mars tal. 12 29/32 `a --/--; plus bas pour mars 12 25/32 à 13/16
Disponsible-; La marché a fluctué entre 54 1/2 et 56 1/2, pour finir à 55 1/2. Il y a bonne demande, sans trop d'engouement cependant.
Franco-Station. –– Nullité complète. .
Contrats. - Nonvelle récolte. Elle est inactive mais se sontient par symathie avec la récoite actuelle et à cause du manque de vendeurs sérieux.
Récolte actuelle. –– Affaires modérnées, mais la tendance rest pour la hausse. On croit à des cours plus élevés..
Dans la matinée ; prix plus haut pour le mars P.T. 57 5/40 à —/—: plus bas pour le mars. 56 25/40 à —/—.
Disponsible. – Le marché est nul.
Contrats-- nouvelle récolte. Pas d'affaires.

Récolte actuelle. On n'y fait pas grand-chose mais avec la dimination rapide de notre stock, et le fair que ce qui reste de marchandise icci est entre les mains des gros exporateurs, les probabilitiés sont en faveur d'une hausse marquée et prochaine.

div.p: gabbari yards.

When t!ie>e depots were visited the whole oods yards were in a congested state, chiefly srupied with cotton and cotton seed tralhc, hioh forms a very large proportion of the tal tonnage. It is desirable to' separate tirely the inwards from the outwards goods, l to increa'O the sired accommodation lor -.sang with outwards good', it will probably 1 e loiind most convenient to use the old pas-, -muon exclusively for the outward Mods to Cairo and l pper Egypt, andtoeu- iose sotue of the existing open sheds ou the • wn side of the yard for the remainder of the i .twards tridlic. ‘lire inwards tralhc is dealt ' with at several dilierent places in a somewhat M.m-cd and expensive manner. This work should be concentrated and etlorts marie to mload the wagons moie rapidly and avoid any unnecessary detention. In this connection it is suggested that the whole of the unloading oi the wagons in these yards be done by contract or piecework, so that the men employed may be distinctly interested m liberating tiie wagons. As 4» hours' free storage has to l-e allowed for the cotton ami cotton seed ■■••riving from the interior, an economy miglrt effected d sullicicnt storage room were ided on which to deposit the tonuuge d to 4s hours' jnward cotton and cotton tralhc.
A visit was paid to the gravitation -idtngs recently completed at great cost, ver one million cubic metres of earth having befcn usecLJn their construction.

As those sidings have only just come into ■,se, it is too early to judge of their working. it was noticed that uoue of the wagons were provided with brakes but that a shoe or slipper was used to control them when descending the grades.

Considering the heavy wagons now employed all over the system, it would probably be wise to tit gradually a suitable hand brake to all wagou stock. Judging by the number in the repairing shop with their ends broken, the working at the gravitation .'tilings will be very expensive unless brakes l-e fitted.

Wagons were not being sorted for stations but only for districts, and it would be a H-rcnt improvement if the trains before leaviug these sidings were made up in such a luanuer as to avoid, as far as possible, sorting and remurshalling when they arrive at the various junctions. This is the object of the second "grid” w hich has not yet been brought into tt'c. but may require re arrangement lor such >se.

e sidings and connections at the Gabbary i department, and the Hues leading to ’ort were carefully examined. They should direiy remodelled, and it is necessary a complete and carefully thought-out plan and scheme should be made. The plan 'hould be designed with a view to future extensions. )

Considering that over two million tons of traffic pass through these yards per annum, und Laving regard to the enormous increase u the trade of the Port of Alexandria, it is desirable that money be spent on the sidings close to' the Port, and it will be found neces- •ary to construct some additional lines under the masonry road bridge which passes over >he goods sidings between the Port and the old passenger station.
It may be quite possible, that for all the improvements required, the expenditure will approach the sum of L.E. 100,000.

div.head: THE NILE FENS
BY I). 0 . HOG AKTH.
(Continued).
CANALS.
div.p: I lie vast soapy bogs, and even wider expanses of I'ormaiieut inundation, are fed by the waste of drains ami canal which spring far up the Delta Hud expire at last unregarded under the face of the dunes; and by a network of forgotten waterways of Ptolemaic and Roman date, wandering now unguidod through the marsh. To meet with one of these in a day’s journey is to lose many auhouriusoekinga ford through the deep’silt from one crumbling bonk to another, aud to endure no mean discomfort stripped urtder a noonday suu for the benefit of moi-quitocs. Only too rarely will y,ou obtain passage in tbo log boat ol a marsbmau, descended from some outlawed reiugee, who spends his days in fishing and his nights prone under a beehive of reeds and mud, which might have sheltered a lake dweller of the Neolithic age. Heliodorus mentions boats ‘rudely hewed out of the rough tree’ which crept about the channels, and ou his excursions from Alexandria about the year 400, he probably saw scenes little diflerent from those which offer themselves in the fenland in the present year of grace.
the behera company.

That I was able in tu,. 'ong run to visit every spot to which 1 had a mind, In a country where the obvious road is usually the least possible, 1 owed mainly to the guides, horses, mules -even steam launches—put at my disposal by the ijocieta Anonyme du Behera. The j advent of this great co'poration is the modern ] event of most importance in these wilds. With a seat in Alexandria, a Board composed of most of the nationalities represented iu that polyglot city, a British managing director, formerly in high place in the Egyptian Department of Public Works, and a stall'of young Britons, Frenchmen, Italians, Greeks, Copts, Armenians, Jews, and what not, this company is achieving the recouquest of the marsh land, I and '’every year the smoke of its traction-1 engines rises nearer the lagoons. Its work is 1 worth the notice of every geographer interested I in the niodification ol the world's surface by I man, aud the approval of everyone concerned I with the ecouomic development of weaker races through the capital and enterprise of the I stronger. The Society began where the local magnates of Ivafres-Sheikh anil Belkas, once called ‘Little Kings of Bcrari,' had been forced to leave off, in despair of the sourness and I saturation of the soils.
A GREAT WORK.

The larger canals and drains had been cut I and embanked through the oozo by Govern rnent labour; but the Society had to construct I the lesser, and, that done, to attack certain I of the nearer and higher-lying lands with great I harrows, which tear and distribute the soapy hummocks, and with steam-ploughs, which open the surface to the drying wind and suu. I Washed with sweet Nile water, the slime was found capable ol bearing rice and barley for I one year or two, aud, purged by such crops, would send up here aud there clover in the I third season, and even a remunerative yield of I cotton. Presently the local husbandmen living I in villages to southward were induced to I take leases, aud ere long to buy. whilo I the steam-engines moved ou into the marsh. I In ten- years the company has built three great model farms and many smaller ones ; J levelled and restored to cultivation thousands and thousands of acres ; abolished a I third of all the marsh in Berari, and caused I population to return to a region where, a generation ago, the lone Coptic Convent of the Apparition of Uur Lady to St. Guemiana was I the last outpost of man. Moreover, native laud-1 owners have now learned something of the I society’s methods, aud far out hi the swamps I many a farm-oasis has been called iuto being I where till lately all was salt and ooze and sand. RECLAMATION.

The process of reclamation is a rapid one, designed to secure a quick return, and the land I is made rather a possible than a very sound sod, for there is little fall and the draining is hardly more than superficial Bat so much amelioration is enough for the native hnsband- inen, and it seems as much as, in a phrase of economics, the 'local traffic will bear.’ Not because it was designed to that end,nor because it is prosecuted with any but a strictly com-1 mercial purpose, to make cent, per cent for I shareholders, this sort of reclamation does, I indeed, effect more for local civilisation than I any Western enterprise with which I am familiar in the Nearer East By its knowledge I and capital this Bclilra Society raises large tracts of land out of a desolation in I which small agriculturists would have had to leave them for over ; and since it aims, I not-to retain these, but to hand them over I to the native, improved up to the point at which he will be capable of dealing with them, it creates no alien latijundia. Small holdings multiply in the wake of its steamers, a fact I which in itself implies no Bmall economic and I social gain, and native human effort is enoonr-1 aged to continue and achieve the local con- quest of natural conditions. The civilisation I so promoted remains one of purely native I spring and character. An indigenous popula I tion is attracted at last into a region long lapsed to wilderness, and there it is induoed I by the building of hamlets, the making of roads and bridges, and the establishment of periodic I markets, to form a settled, stable, and self helping society—all, if you will, to the groat I profit of an alien corporation, but obviously to I the still greater profit oi the land of Egypt. I
A LAND OF DESOLATION.
Raised even at this day less than a metre I at most above sea level, impossible to drain I thoroughly by any natural wator-flow, sodden
with all the salts of Nile, wild, unteuante seeming,' if any on earth,
A wAAt laud where uo man Come*.
Nor hath entne, since* the makbig of tho work!,

the Nile fen, nevertheless, is full of hums memorial' There are few sights more astonisl iug than that of mounds, covering nearly tw score of buried towns, in that water-logge desolation ; and I am still at a loss to explai how so large a population, dependent pn sumably for the most part on agriculture,cam to settle and subsist there iu an age to wbic pumps and any but the simplest methods drainage were uukuown. That it practise agriculture, and did not live by fishing alone, i abundantly proved by the maze of old irrigi tion channels anddrainsaboutthemounds. Yo may even descry here and there, on the bight (tarts of the present marsh,a trace of ridge an furrow. In the main the culture must hav been of cereals. Since Egypt, as is well knowi was long the main feeder of the city of Rorni it need furprisc no one that every arable iuc in the Nile Valley should have been pressed t produce. Wheat, and doubtless on the saltt lands barley, must have paid the Delta cu tivator in those days at least as we as cotton does now. But it should not b forgotten that he made a profit also in Imperii times out o‘t other oultures long forgotten i Egypt, such as those of the vine and olivi From the first was produced, in the. mars! land of Mareotis, a wine celebrated in th Roman w->rld : and there are sufficient remain of oil presses lying on the surface of th Berori mounds to prove the former existenc of olive groves in the locality. But how t explain such cultures in such a district 1 Th experienced Europeans now eugaged in re claiming it are convinced that they would b impossible now, owing to the excessive satura tion and saliuity ; and, indeed, one can liardl; avoid belief in some subsequent subsideno of the land, such as, indeed, may be provet to have actually taken place not very far away where the foundations of Ptolemaic palaces an to be seen awash in the eastern bay of Alex andria. ANCIENT towns.

It is certain, however, not only as mj tentative digging proved, from the elevatioi of the towns on artificial mounds, but alsc from the very little that can be learned of the district in ancient writings, that it was alwayi to some extent a fen. More tlian once ic history rebels against the Egyptian Pharaohi found security in the northern swamps ; and the holy city Buto, whose oracle and festival are mentioned by Herodotus, is said tc have lain on the edge of a great marsh. Its site, perhaps the most important still not certaiuly identified in Lower Egypt, was somewhere in the 6outli wext of the fen region ; and a probable site has been found on the great mounds ol Farain, a low miles north of the Bcrari railway and ten from the east bank of the Rosetta Nile. Moreover, there is that actual desdription of a great tract of swamp and islands in this part of Egypt left by Heliodorus. His dainty romance of the loves of Theagenes and Charicleia, the best and almost the only novel in ancient Greek, which is said (probably without truth) to have drawn down on its episcopal author the censure of a startled syuod, thus describes the marshes (I quote the rendering of the Elizabethan translator, Uuderdown):—
THE PASTURE OF THE EGYPTIANS

“The whole place is called the Pasture of the Egyptian', about the which is a lowe valley, which receivetli oertaine exuudations ofNylus, by means whereof it becometh a poole, and is in the midst very deepe, about the brimmes whereof are mar! ihes or fenues. For looke, as the shore is to tho Sea, such is the Fennea to every great Poole. In that place have the theeves of Egypt, how many soever they bee, their common wealth. And for as much as there is a little land without the water, some live iu small cottages, others in boates which they use as wel for their house as for passage over the poole. In these doe their1 women sorve them, and it need require, be also brought to bedde. When a child is borne first, they let him sucke hismother’.siiiilkawhile.butafter they feede him with fishes taken in the lake and roasted in the hoato suniie. And when they perceive that lie beginnes to goe, they tie a cord about his legs, and suffer him but onely to goe about the boate... Moroovertliegreat plenty ofreede that groweth there in the Moozy ground is in a manner as good as a bulwark to them. For by- devising many orooked and cumbrous wayes, through which the passage to them by oft use is very easie, but to others hard, they have made it as a sure defence, that by no sudden invasion they may be endammaged.”

div.p: -• do not bold oanaitw for lb ronioMlbU aptataw by our ourrMpoiklaoM. bnl w* wish. Is • W*r'' . ' l*> to *11. lo psrmlt _ wUhin wWU "■■W liSM-ftn
VANDALISM AT ALEXANDRIA.
To the Editor op the Egyptian G lzktte.

Sir,— A visitor to Alexandria, who knew the town before 1862 and has not seen it since, will be justly astonished, on viewing it again now, at the great progress that has been made, not only in building up what bad been wantonly destroyed, but also in enlarging and embellishing the town. One of my friends came here some days ago for the first time, so he could not have this experience ; but having been firet to Upper Egypt, be was encliantod with what he bad seen, and spoke a good deal about the splendour of the effects of light iu the Nile Valley and the majestic grandeur of the ancient monuments. I told him that I would show him, iu modern Alexandria, a feat of modern construction, and took him to the old port to let him have a look over the new quay, which is well worth seeing.^ Arrived there, we glanced over the great extension of the semi-cirole effected by that extensive work of modern engineering art, but when 1 looked to the West I rubbed my eyes, for that old fortress of Kait Bey, that offered such a fine view with its solid mass against the evening sky, was deprived of its tower, and traces of further destruction were to be seen at a great distanoe. I told my friend that some accident must have wrought this devastation. On inquiry, however, I found-out that this was only an example of what we may well call “Modern Vandalism. The old fort, which so picturesquely stood out against the western sky, the green waves dashing up against its walls,—the majeotio old fortress, marking the spot where once iu the olden times one qf the seven wonders of the world had been erected, is being pulled down so that the stones may be used for buildings for the Coast Guards. Why 1 this is about as bad as the destruction of the Pyramids and the other old Egyptian monuments which have been used as quarries by people who did not know better and whom we to day indiguantly call “Vandals'. „

It is true, the price of building material has gone up daring the last few years, but has the sense of the a*sthetio gone down in proportion 1 How is it tjiatthe City Fathers, who have been entrusted to look alter the town's welfare, have not understood wHkt they have allowed to be done 11s there not one amongst them to point out that one ol the very few views thistownhas, is being destroyed for futile reasons 1 Must the old ifert by-and-by cometo look like an immense bath-tub of cement T

They are speaking of building a promenade- pier. What are the promeuadere going to look at 1 Other towns would erect a monument there t-j/imrk in a picturesque way the western end of^the bay and the spot where the old ‘ Pharos” fltood, which made the name of Alexandria famthttf^nTblden times, when millions were apeut by a population which had a keen sense of the beautiful. Now, for a question of perhaps not even-a thousand pounds, it is decided at the green table, which does not even stand in this town, that Fort Kait-Bey must be pulled down to use the btoues, not considering that many parts of the old landmark also have an architectural and historical value. While this is beingdone still the question is not decided whether the Roman Tower, that horrible and uuinteresting heap of stones, -hall be built up again at great cost. The “Comity pour la conservation des monuments de Part arabe" has tqken the Roman Tower under its wings. It is neither “art nor arabe ; Where is this “Comittf” now, when it might stepinto protect what is of much more interest l Why does the Municipality not send in the most energetic protest it can form! Because the fortress is not under its jurisdiction 1 • Has the town no right to demand that its •esthetic outlines be not disfigured in the interests of an administration which, on the other hand, is created to protect its material intereits VYet it is perhaps time, and I am sure that if nothing else will help, Lord Cromer will certainly find by his calculations that (pr the Coast-Guards the money for stones can be found without destroying one of the few views on which the eyes of those like to rest, who take their pleasure not only in looking at figures. Lord Cromer would certainly help the Municipality in doing what I think is its duty if only ho knew. Believe me, Sir, yours truly,
“Deltaner”.
Alexandria, March 3.

div.head: Reduced Rates on Sudan Government
div.p: Railways and Steamers.
IjABOUHEHS for Agricultural Pi rposrh.
A reduction of 3rd class passenger fares will be granted to Landowners importing labourers for agricultural purposes under the following conditions:—

(a) A robate of 20 per cent, will be granted upon the Sudan Government Steamers and Railways to all parti as of agricultural labourers of not less than 10 persons enter­ing the Sudan from Egypt on their journey from Aswan to any destination in the Sudan.
(5) No rebate will be allowed upon the fare for any local journey within the Sudan or upon any fare for a journey from the Sudan to Egypt.
(c) No rebate will be allowed on any ticket other than 3rd class. Rebates on 4 th class fares cannot be. given.
(</) In order to obtain the rebate, a receipt lor the tickets issued must be obtained nt the time the tickets are taken.
(e) The rebate must bo claimed at the end of each quarter from the Director of Rail­ways for the railway fares, and from the Director of Steamers and Boats for the steamer fares.
All claims mast be supported by the re­ceipts mentioned in the preceding para­graph or they will not bo entertained.
( /) All rebates will cease upon the opening of the Nile — lied Sea Railway to traffic.

(y) In order to obtain the robate a certificate must be obtained from the Agent General to the Sudan Government, War Office, Cairo, stating the name of the potion importing the labourers (Landowner), the number of labourers, and their destination.

Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.

This Company is formed for the purposes set oat in its Memorandum of Assoui ition, and in particular to oonduct business in Egypt and the Soudan, as opportunity affords, and more particnlarly:—'
To purchase, lease, hire and secure concessions of land eithor in town or country.
To reclaim, improve, cultivate, develop, lease, or otherwise deal with Properties when acquired.
To develop building land by the erection of houses or otherwise.
To advance money on mortgage or otherwise, to acquire mortgage or other securities either individually or jointly with others.
To instal irrigation works, supplying the necessary plant for the purpose; to construct canals, drains, roads and tramways, and to carry on industries connected with Agricultural enterprises.
To carry on any business whiob may be profitably or conveniently worked in connection with any of the foregoing enterprises.

Egypt presents a large field for profitable employment of money in lending on safe mortgage. The gross value of land in Egypt is put by expertsat £300,000,000, an average value of £50 per fed dan on 6,000,000 feddans.

The advance in prosperity of the country owing to British Administration, the Anglo-Frenob Agreement, and the recent proposed official introduction of the English language into the Mixed Tribunals is well known. The value of land in Egypt for agricultural and building purposes is shewn by innumerable sales and ro-sales at c instantly enhanced prices, and by the market quotation of Land Companies operating in Egypt, and it is believed that opportunities will occur of securing lana which should greatly increase in valuo within a short space of time

Owing to the increase in the population of the larger towns of Egypt, there is a very healthy and steady demand for well-boilt houses, and in the purchase development and resale ot estates for residential and other purpose, ample soope for remunerative business is afforded; it is considered that from this source the Company sh.iuld derive a fair income.

The opening of Government lands in the Soudan should not oTiTy afford favourable opp irtunity for investing large Capital amounts on mortgage for many years to come, bnt also offer favourable opportunities for purchase and development. The conversion of burin land to ca- nalistd tummer cultivation in Middle Egypt, the regular reclamation and improvement of salt Iona in Lower Egypt offer additional oocasion for profitable business.

The c'imate of Egypt is such, and the richness of the soil is so great, that crops can bo grown continuously, the land not requiring to lie fallow. The land in Lower Bgypt grows a winter crop of beans, wheat, barley, clover, &c., and again a summer crop of cotton, rioe or mmte, besides minor crops of numerous kinds of vegetables. The chief products are ootton, wheat, maize, barley, rice, beans, lentils, peas, rape, lettuoe, mustard, saffron, capsicum, aniseed, sugar cane, figs dates, oranges, lemons, melons, mandarins, limes, &c., &c.
The Articles of Association provide as follows

' As remuneration for his services as a Director, the Chairman shall receive remuneration at the rate of £250 per annum, and the other Directors shall eaph receive remuneration at the rate cf £200 per annum. In addition to the said fix^d remuneration there shall be divided between the Directors in such manner as they Riay determine a sum equal to 10 per bent! on the profits certified by the Auditors of the' Company to have'been made in each year in exoess of a sum sufficient to provide a dividend ot 7 per oeht upon the amount paid up or credited as paid up on the Ordinary Shares for the time being, having regard to the provisions as to the division of profits hereinbefore oontained, but without making any provision for a Reserve Fund. The Directors for the time being may from time to time appoint one or more of their body to bo tho Mauaging Director or Managing Directors of the Company, either for a fixed term or without any limitation as to the period for which he or they is or are to hold soon office, and may from time to time remove or dismiss him or them from office and appoint auother or others in his or their place or places. The remuneration of a Managing Director or a Director or Directors acting as managers shall from time to time be fixed by the Directors, and may be by way of salary or oommission, or participation in profits, or by any or/and all of these modes. If any Director, being willing, shall be called upon to perform extra servioe, or to make any special exertiouB in going or residing abroad, or otherwise, <br any of the purposes of the Company, or act as Trustee for the Company or its DebJutu re Hplders, and shall ao so, the Company may remunerate snob Director, either oy a fixed sum or by a percentage ot profits, or otherwise, as may be determined by the Directors, and suoh remuneration may be either in addition to or in substitution for nis remuneration above provided.

Applications for Sliares should be made on the accompanying form and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company's Bankers. If no allotment is made, the Application money will he returned in full, and where the number of Shares allotted is less than that applied for the surplus will be credited in reduction of the amount payable on allotment, and any excess will be returned to tho Applicant.
Failure to j>ay any instalment when due will render the previous payments liable to be forfeited.

A copy of the Memorandum of Ass 'ciation, with names, addresses and descriptions of the Signatories thereof and the number of Shares subscribed for by them respectively will be found in the fold of the Prospectus, of which it forms part.
The minimum subscription upon which the Directors may proceed to Allotment has been fixed by the Articles of Association at £100,000.

The estimated preliminary expenses of the Company, including registration fees and advertising and issuing this Prospectus in this, oountry and in Egypt, and all other expenses, except brokerage on application for shares, and • Stamps on Share 'Warrants, amount to six thousand pounds; and in relation thereto a Contract dated the 22nd day of Fobruary, 1905. has been made between George Hamilton Craig of the one part, and Sydney William Bartman, as Trustee for the Company^ of the other part, whereby the Companyiagrees to pay six. thousand pounds lor such preliminary oxpenxeu, tho said George Hamilton Craig being entitled to retain any difference between the preli urinary expenses and six thousand pounds, and undertaking to pay any sum by which the estimate shall fall short
A brokerage of Sixpenoe per Share will be paid to Brokers and Bankers on all Shares applied for and alloted to the public on Application Forms hearing their stamps.
Application will be made to the Committee of the London Stock Exchange in due oourse for a settlement and quotation of the Company's Snstws.
Print of die Memorandum and Artiolea of Association of the Company, and oopy of the above-mentioned Contract, can be inspected at the Office of the Solicitors to thS.Company.
Copies of this Proepeotus and Application Forms can be obtained at the Offices of the Company, the Jankers .and Solicitors.
